## The problem of induction

> "That the sun will *not* rise tomorrow is no less intelligible a proposition that that it will rise. We should in vain, therefore, attempt to demonstrate its falsehood." â€“Hume quoted in @diaconis2018

-   Inductive inferences do not follow a logical deductions from their premises

-   But surprisingly effective?

## Pierce on inference

-   Peirce is famous for contributing the idea of what he called 'abduction'

    -   Renamed by philosophers 'inference to the best explanation'

-   This is **not** a solution to the problem of induction

## Pierce on induction

> "...a process which would more often yield truth than the reverse" [@hacking1990, p. 209]

-   This is at the core of his idea

-   Inductive inference: 'the conclusion is **usually** true when the premises are true'

## Pierce on induction

> "When the premises are quantitative, we may be able to replace the 'usually' by a numerical probability. **That does not mean that conclusion has a probability of such and such.** Rather: the conclusion is reached by an argument that, with such and such a probability, gives true conclusions from true premises." [@hacking1990, p. 209 emphasis added].

-   '...Peirce was providing the core of the rationale of the theory of confidence intervals' [@hacking1990, p. 210]

## Intuition

```{r}
#| label: ci-simulation
#| message: false
#| warning: false
#| fig-cap: "Simulation of Confidence Intervals (89% Level)"

library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork) # Optional but great for combining plots, though facets work here too

# 1. Set Parameters
set.seed(89)         # For reproducibility
mu_true <- 0         # True population mean
sigma <- 1           # True population standard deviation
n_sample <- 30       # Sample size drawn per experiment
conf_level <- 0.89   # 89% Confidence level
sim_steps <- c(1, 10, 100, 10000) # The steps we want to visualize

# 2. Generate the Master Data (1000 total simulations)
# We generate the max needed (1000) and then filter for the plots
max_sims <- max(sim_steps)

master_data <- tibble(sim_id = 1:max_sims) %>%
  rowwise() %>%
  mutate(
    # Generate random sample
    data = list(rnorm(n_sample, mean = mu_true, sd = sigma)),
    
    # Calculate stats
    x_bar = mean(unlist(data)),
    s = sd(unlist(data)),
    se = s / sqrt(n_sample),
    
    # Critical Value (t-distribution)
    alpha = 1 - conf_level,
    t_crit = qt(1 - alpha / 2, df = n_sample - 1),
    
    # Intervals
    ci_lower = x_bar - t_crit * se,
    ci_upper = x_bar + t_crit * se,
    
    # Check if we captured the mean
    captured = ifelse(ci_lower <= mu_true & ci_upper >= mu_true, 
                      "Captured", "Missed")
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# 3. Create a combined dataset for plotting
# We duplicate rows to assign them to different "View" groups (1, 10, 100, 1000)
plot_data <- map_dfr(sim_steps, function(k) {
  
  # Slice the first k simulations
  subset_data <- master_data %>% slice(1:k)
  
  # Calculate empirical coverage for this specific subset
  coverage_rate <- mean(subset_data$captured == "Captured")
  
  # Return data with a labeling column for the facet
  subset_data %>%
    mutate(
      n_sims_label = factor(k, levels = sim_steps),
      facet_title = paste0("Sims: ", k, " | Coverage: ", round(coverage_rate * 100, 1), "%")
    )
})

# ensure factor order for plotting
plot_data$facet_title <- factor(plot_data$facet_title, levels = unique(plot_data$facet_title))

# 4. Plot
ggplot(plot_data, aes(y = sim_id)) +
  # Draw the CI lines
  geom_segment(aes(x = ci_lower, xend = ci_upper, y = sim_id, yend = sim_id, color = captured), 
               linewidth = 0.6) +
  # Draw the sample means
  geom_point(aes(x = x_bar, color = captured), size = 1) +
  # Draw the True Mean line
  geom_vline(xintercept = mu_true, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.5) +
  
  # Facet by the simulation count groups
  facet_wrap(~facet_title, scales = "free_y", ncol = 2) +
  
  # Colors
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Captured" = "gray50", "Missed" = "#D55E00")) +
  
  # Labels and Theme
  labs(
    title = paste0("Calibration of ", conf_level*100, "% Confidence Intervals"),
    subtitle = "As N simulations increases, empirical coverage converges to theoretical 89%",
    x = "Estimate Value",
    y = "Experiment ID",
    color = "Result"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
    strip.text = element_text(face = "bold", size = 11),
    panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank()
  )
```
